headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Ruben Amorim sack decision, Neves message, Carlos Baleba boost
body: United do not play this midweek after failing to qualify for any UEFA competition last term and following their League Cup second round exit to Grimsby Town. However, there is no shortage of focus on them following their 3-0 defeat to Manchester City in the derby.

Even though the summer window has closed, transfer talk has remained with Ruben Neves emerging as the latest midfielder of interest. Elliot Anderson, Carlos Baleba and Adam Wharton have also been linked with moves to Old Trafford.
We will cover all the latest transfer news and rumours, plus any further developments on Amorim's future and other more general club updates with our live blog below.
Manchester United midfielder Casemiro is being considered by Saudi Arabian side Al-Nassr, according to reports from Spain.

The Brazilian's deal expires next summer, meaning he will be available to depart the club as a free agent. Casemiro's arrival in Erik ten Hag's first transfer window has been heavily criticised, particularly with him signing a four-year deal.

While he impressed in his first campaign under Ten Hag, the Real Madrid legend's dynamism has often been questioned, particularly within Ruben Amorim's 3-4-3 system. However, Spanish outlet Mundo Deportivo understands Al-Nassr, who Cristiano Ronaldo plays for, are considering a move for the 33-year-old.
Manchester United are considering a move for Brentford midfielder Yehor Yarmolyuk, who is a cheaper alternative to Carlos Baleba.

Midfield has emerged as a glaring weakness for Ruben Amorim's side. The Red Devils were interested in a move for Baleba, but pulled their interest not long after Brighton and Hove Albion said he could cost £100million.

Reports from Ukrainian outlet Dynamo.kiev.ua claim the Red Devils have been impressed by Yarmolyuk's performances for the Bees. It also claims United are "serious contenders" for the 21-year-old, who may cost around £30m.

Amorim has been insisting on deploying his 3-4-3 formation with Bruno Fernandes operating as one of the two defensive midfielders in his system. It has so far been exposed on multiple occasions and was painfully picked apart by City at the Etihad Stadium.
Peter Schmeichel has blasted Manchester United for getting rid of Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund.

The former Red Devils duo are both starring for Napoli, with the latter recently scoring on his debut for the Neapolitans. Meanwhile, McTominay was named as the Serie A MVP last season, after winning the title with Antonio Conte's side.

Looking back on the decisions, Schmeichel admits he cannot understand why the club parted with the duo. Speaking to Sky Bet, Schmeichel said: "I’d say Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund are the two players who should never have left."
He added: "The one that really pains me is Hojlund. I honestly believe he could have been a 25-goal-a-season striker for Manchester United.

"The problem wasn’t him – it was the way the team played. The system didn’t suit him. When players like [Alejandro] Garnacho or [Marcus] Rashford got the ball, they looked only to shoot. The ball into the number nine never came, even though Rasmus was making really good runs."
When referring to Scott McTominay, he added: "As for McTominay, I honestly can’t say anything other than: why? Why was he allowed to leave?"
Paul Scholes believes Manchester United need to part with Harry Maguire and Luke Shaw.

The United legend was commenting on the Red Devils' 3-0 defeat to Manchester City the previous weekend. Shaw started as Ruben Amorim's left-wing-back, while Maguire came on from the bench against Pep Guardiola's side.

For City's first goal, Jeremy Doku got the better of the ex-Southampton defender, who then failed to track Phil Foden's run before the England international headed in the opener. Speaking to Sportbible, Scholes said: "I don't think the system was the problem against Manchester City.
"It's more the personnel. United lack real athletes. In the Premier League, you almost have to be like a machine to survive, and we've got people like Harry Maguire and Luke Shaw.
"They are not at the level. In 85 to 90 percent of games, they will probably cope with people.
"But when you come to the bigger games, against City, Liverpool and Arsenal, they are going to fall short."
Conor Gallagher is one of many midfielders Manchester United were interested in during the summer transfer window with a late approach made for the former Chelsea man.
TBR Football have now stated he is becoming irate regarding his predicament at Atletico Madrid with just two starts out of a possible five made. Their report did state he is happy, though.
This comes following updates from journalist Graeme Bailey over Gallagher possibly moving elsewhere in January.
As with many players at this moment in time, the World Cup is an added complication or worry.
Gallagher is one of those players who, if playing regularly, at his best, would be firmly in contention for his national side, so that issue can’t be overlooked.

I am told the player would dearly like to make it back into the Atletico Madrid side and that is his priority, but clubs are paying real interest to him and he is very much one to keep an eye on for January.
Chelsea may be sweating on the availability of Cole Palmer ahead of their Premier League clash against Manchester United.

The Blues' talisman made his first start in nearly one month against Bayern Munich and scored for the second consecutive game after grabbing a goal in the 2-2 draw with Brentford off the bench last weekend.

He played the full 90 minutes at Allianz Arena and appeared to be holding his groin in the latter stages of the clash. When asked about that, Enzo Maresca said: "Cole, I think he's okay. I asked him after the game, he said that he's okay."
There were also concerns over Trevoh Chalobah after he clutched his shoulder following a dual with Harry Kane. After receiving treatment, he came back on and completed the game.
Liam Delap, Romeo Lavia, Benoit Badiashile, Dario Essugo and Levi Colwill are all expected to miss out.
The agent of Diego Leon, Renato Bittar, has been speaking about his clients move to Manchester United.
He is yet to play any competitive minutes for his new club but has been training with the first-team despite the initial expectation being that he would be playing for the under-21s.
Speaking to Versus Radio, Bittar has stated that Leon is “happy with how he is enjoying it, being the first Paraguayan at Manchester United."
He added: “I think he will bring a lot of joy to the fans as he is very focused and psychologically prepare."
Rasmus Hojlund is another Manchester United loannee returning to England this evening as Manchester City face his Napoli side in the Champions League.
Hojlund departed United in the final week of the summer transfer window to join the Italian side following Romelu Lukaku's long-term injury.

He scored on his debut for Napoli and now some details regarding his final few months at the club have emerged. According to the Athletic, he was plagued by a foot injury in the latter stages of last season but he insisted on still playing.
Their report added he was told following the Carabao Cup defeat to Grimsby Town that he had no future at the club.
Marcus Rashford will be back in England this evening as Barcelona face Newcastle United in the Champions League.

The Manchester United academy graduate has made a bright start to his loan spell in Spain with a start at St James' Park a real possibility as Lamine Yamal is out injured. Flick also praised the 27-year-old in his pre-match press conference.
"You have to look back a little, I've followed Marcus since Manchester United - he has speed, one-on-one skills, and finishing.

"What I've seen in the first few weeks has been very good, and he has some more potential to show. It's great to have him on the team. He's an incredible, fantastic player. What I'm seeing is very good."
Manchester United have reported revenues of £164 million for the fourth quarter of the trading period for the year ended June 30, 2025.
Following a disastrous season which concluded with a Europa League final defeat to Tottenham, that is a pretty impressive financial return.
Any major concerns over breaching profit and sustainability rules may no longer be there and it could help United in their renewed pursuit of Carlos Baleba.
Brighton quoted a triple-figure sum when approached by United for the midfielder but it could actually be a figure that United can reach next summer.
Ruben Neves appears to be Manchester United's newest midfield transfer target.

The Portugal international currently plays his football out in Saudi Arabia and recently hit an impressive milestone for Al-Hilal by making his 100th appearance for the club. Following their social media message to him, Neves replied with a blue heart emoji.
Prior to that, the former Wolves man sent a clear message, via A Bola, which appears to hand United a transfer boost if they pursue his services.
I've said it in all the interviews - it's not coming back to finish your career, it's going back to play and be competitive: that's my big goal.

Fortunately, I'm 28 years old and I feel very good physically. This is a career goal, because I wasn't champion at Porto and having a family of over 60 people who support the club, it's something I want to give them and experience [for myself].
I used to go to the Aliados to celebrate Porto's titles but now I want to be on the other side and want to see my family celebrate.
The former Napoli player Ivano Trotta believes they have got a bargain in Rasmus Hojlund.
He has told 1 Station Radio:

Rasmus Hojlund is an extraordinary player. He really impressed me against Fiorentina. He has incredible qualities. The €40-50m spent is justified because we are talking about a young talent with great potential.
In the end, things turned out well because Hojlund has shown himself to be a very strong footballer, and for the price Napoli paid, they got a bargain.
Joleon Lescott does not believe United needed to sign Matheus Cunha.
Lescott said speaking on In The Mixer, brought to you by Sky Bet:
I reckon Mbeumo has a more impactful season than Cunha. They don't need [a player like Cunha]. Mbeumo is more of a foundational piece to their puzzle than Cunha.
Peter Schmeichel claims to have been asking Gianluigi Donnarumma to join United for over a year.
He said on CBS:
I have been talking to him for actually more than a year. Pulled him, and 'I asked you to come to Man United, and you are in the wrong club here', and all he said was 'I am happy'.
Senne Lammens has already impressed United goalkeeper Tom Heaton in training.
The veteran shot-stopper said on the Training Ground Guru podcast:

It’s only been a few days of training, but he seems like a really good lad. He’s calm, but a strong personality. His goalkeeping fundamentals are very impressive, and I think I said that to him after a couple of days of training! Twenty-three years old coming into Manchester United, first few days training and he’s been very impressive so far.
City are said to be considering a move for Kobbie Mainoo.

TEAMtalk claims Chelsea and Newcastle also have the central midfielder on their radars. Pep Guardiola reportedly views the 20-year-old player highly compared to other English players of a similar age, while Eddie Howe is another reputed admirer of Mainoo.
Gianluigi Donnarumma has delivered a damning verdict on United's recent transfer business before City play Napoli tonight.
Asked whether there was a player he was particularly worried about facing, the new goalkeeper said:
For me, one of the most dangerous is [Scott] McTominay, but I'm also thinking about [Rasmus] Hojlund
Rumours about Bournemouth head coach Andoni Iraola replacing Ruben Amorim are said to be simply speculation.
Fabrizio Romano has clarified the situation to GIVEMESPORT:
Nothing about names now, at the moment, Man United are not changing the coach, so all the rest is speculation. If something changes with Amorim, we'll see who they pick.
Napoli manager Antonio Conte has backed Rasmus Hojlund to succeed at Napoli after enduring a tough spell at Manchester United.

Hojlund, who completed his loan move to Serie A during the summer transfer window, netted his first goal for the club against Fiorentina last weekend. Hojlund opened his account on debut after Napoli bolstered their attacking options in the wake of an injury to former United striker Romelu Lukaku.

He has already made an impact for the reigning Italian champions, and Conte is confident the striker has even more to offer. The Napoli boss has thrown his full support behind Hojlund ahead of Thursday night's Champions League clash with Manchester City.

He said: "I knew Rasmus because he played with Atalanta and then he came to Man United. In my opinion we are talking about a player with great potential and he is only 22, so he has a whole career ahead of him. When we spoke with him, I felt he was really happy to get this new experience and he said he was ready and wanted to play for me and for Napoli..."

Former defender Mikael Silvestre insists a change of management is not necessary at Old Trafford despite ongoing doubts over Amorim following United's poor start to the 2025/26 campaign.

"It’s too early, I think, to draw the line," Silvestre said. "Clearly, for me. There’s still a lot of work to be done. Hopefully, he will be given the time, the support and the players’ commitment to improve.

"You know it’s going to take time to improve, and the question is if we’re going to see improvement in December, in January, because we’ve got to look at that. I think you have to push it to the point that if there’s no immediate danger to be relegated, you give him time to build something and work with the players.

"They will need to get results. They will need to get stuck in. There’s a lot of things which, you put that together and it’s difficult to see the bright side, but you have to be patient and stick with your decision until the point where you say: this is going to work or it’s not going to work. I think it’s too early to make that decision yet."
According to the Daily Mail, Man United have set their sights on goalkeeping prodigy Alfie Smith.

Despite being just 14, he has already made his U18 debut for the club, becoming “the second youngest keeper ever to appear at Premier League Under-18 level” last weekend when he kept goal for Birmingham in a 4-3 win at Fulham.
He also became Birmingham's youngest U18 debutant and is praised for being comfortable with both feet, as well as an excellent shot-stopper.

The report adds that the Championship side is looking to secure the goalkeeper prospect, working to convince the highly rated teenager and his family that the best pathway for his future career remains at St Andrew's.
There has been a lot of talk over the future of Manchester United midfielder Kobbie Mainoo over the last few days with his long-term future at Old Trafford remaining unclear.
The 20-year-old has fallen down the pecking order under Ruben Amorim. His one start so far this season came in the Carabao Cup penalty shootout loss against League Two side Grimsby Town.

His lack of starts comes after the player asked to go out on loan this summer, a request refused by United. It has since emerged that French side OGC Nice were one of the clubs interested in signing him. There is now more talk over his future with eyes starting to turn to the January transfer window.
Read more here.
Portugal international Ruben Neves has reportedly emerged as a surprise candidate to strengthen Man United's midfield.

It's no surprise of the need for United to strengthen their midfield, with evidence, this season, suggesting that Bruno Fernandes would be better off higher up the pitch. Fernandes' work ethic, ball-winning ability, and vision allow him to play in a deeper midfield role, but he struggles to produce his best performances there.

The Daily Briefing have reported that the Portugal international is open to returning to European football after two years at Al-Hilal. With his contract running until the summer of 2026, Neves can open talks in January over a pre-agreement.

The 28-year-old previously played in the Premier League with Wolves between 2017 and 2023. The report also notes that Newcastle United and Tottenham are expected to compete for the player's signature, while Amorim is said to have a 'particularly strong interest' in signing him.

However, Neves made his future plans clear when speaking to the Portuguese channel Sport TV earlier this summer. The midfielder, who came through FC Porto's youth setup, left the club at 20, missing out on the chance to win silverware with his boyhood team..

He emphasised his desire to return and compete for titles. "I've said it in all the interviews - it's not coming back to finish your career, it's going back to play and be competitive: that's my big goal," he said last month.

"Fortunately, I'm 28 years old and I feel very good physically. This is a career goal, because I wasn't champion at Porto and having a family of over 60 people who support the club, it's something I want to give them and experience [for myself]. I used to go to the Aliados to celebrate Porto's titles but now I want to be on the other side and want to see my family celebrate."
Paul Merson has suggested that Newcastle United transfer target Mainoo “has got to be asking himself serious questions” over his lack of game time at Manchester United.

The 20-year-old has yet to start a Premier League match this season and was on the bench for Sunday’s heavy defeat at Manchester City. He came on in the 62nd minute and made an impact, registering 25 touches, a 100% pass success rate, and two key passes.

Some Manchester United fans are now calling on Ruben Amorim to start Mainoo against Chelsea on Saturday as the Reds look for just their second win of the season. The Stockport-born midfielder has featured for only 73 minutes in the league this campaign, having remained an unused substitute against Arsenal and Fulham.

"He came on the other day against Man City and I thought he did well, at least he had a go. But he needs to be playing for them from the start, but I don't know why. For me, it's quite worrying because the kid has got talent, he is a Man United lad, come through the ranks and he is not playing. He is the only one that can answer that."
Omar Berrada insists that Man United are building for the 'long term' in a message signalling his support for Ruben Amorim.

The United boss is under increasing pressure after they collected just one win from their first five games of the season. United spent £216million on new signings in the summer transfer window and CEO Berrada believes that the club is set up for future success.

On Wednesday, United announced their financial results for 2024-2025, boasting record revenues of £666.5m. In a statement, ex-Manchester City chief Berrada said: "As we settle into the 2025/26 season, we are working hard to improve the club in all areas. On the field, we are pleased with the additions we have made to our men's and women's first-team squads over the summer, as we build for the long term."

Berrada's comments suggest that the United hierarchy still believe Amorim is the man to bring the glory days back to Old Trafford. But following Sunday's comprehensive 3-0 defeat in the Manchester derby, reports emerged claiming that United are already assessing options to replace him.
The Mirror also add that Amorim effectively has three games to save his job before October's international break.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s Ineos are set to make an announcement very soon that could have a major impact on Man United. The Ineos businessman completed a £1.25bn deal to acquire the Red Devils in February last year.

Previous reports have claimed that Ratcliffe is ready to sell his stake in Nice, while some reports have claimed that an announcement could be on the way. As per French outlet Ici, an announcement from Ineos is expected 'in the coming days'.

The content of the statement is still under wraps but Nice boss Franck Haise has called for clarity from the current owners. Speaking recently, he said: "Lots of us are waiting for the owners to speak. I hope that it will happen. But it isn’t my subject. My subject is the players, the staff, the matches, and the season. It is the only thing I can impact. The subject of the owners isn’t mine."
Despite that, Ratcliffe’s influence has waned over recent years. UEFA's multi-club ownership rules preventing Ineos from investing in the side last season.

The Daily star claim that four managers are among the potential replacements should Amorim leave Man United.

United have collected only four points from their opening four Premier League games, leaving them 14th in the table. United will host Chelsea at Old Trafford on Saturday, before travelling to Brentford and then facing newly-promoted Sunderland at home ahead of the international break.
According to the report, Crystal Palace manager Oliver Glasner, former England boss Gareth Southgate, Fulhamchief Marco Silva and Bournemouth's Andoni Iraola, are viewed as potential replacements.
United defender Lisandro Martinez has teased his return from injury with an image of him training on the grass at Carrington.

Since February, the 27-year-old has been sidelined with an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury and has been a huge loss for Ruben Amorim. Taking to Instagram on Wednesday afternoon, Martinez posted an image of him undergoing individual training with a member of staff.
Gianluigi Donnarumma is said to have initially preferred a move to United over City this summer.
The journalist Rory Smith said on BBC Radio 5 Live during the Monday Night Club.

I’m not 100% certain of this, but what I have heard, which isn’t always accurate, is that Donnarumma preferred United over City initially, because of the glamour of United, but United couldn’t get close to the money that he wanted, and City could, so he was perfectly happy to do that.
David Ornstein has acknowledged not knowing of any set number of matches Ruben Amorim has to save his job as United head coach.
The journalist said on Tuesday night's edition of Back Pages:
I think it's logical to understand that this can't continue. I don't know about a set number of games. I don't think United are minded to be changing manager again already.

headline: RAILSTON: Bryan Robson disagrees with Ruben Amorim about two Manchester United issues
body: Manchester United legend Bryan Robson believes Ruben Amorim needs to be tactically flexible.

Amorim oversaw the worst season at Old Trafford for 51 years following his appointment from Sporting Lisbon in November. Amorim needed to start the new campaign well, but United have made their worst start to a season for 33 years and speculation has begun about his future.
United suffered a 3-0 defeat against Manchester City last weekend, which means Amorim has the worst win percentage of any permanent United manager since the Second World War.
Amorim said: "When I want to change my philosophy, I will change. If not, you have to change the man. I believe in my way and I am going to play my way until I want to change."
Some fans believe Amorim's system was never a good fit for the club, while others have suggested the 40-year-old change his formation to secure results and ease pressure.
Sky will show at least 215 live Premier League games this season, an increase of up to 100 more.
United legend Robson spoke to OLBG and shared his verdict: "I feel as a manager you have to have a few tactics up your sleeve. Otherwise people know how to set up against you.

"If you're playing the same way week in, week out, the opposition, and especially with all the technology and everything nowadays, you can go out on the training pitch and you set yourself up to do well against a team. That's why I feel he's got to be a bit more flexible.

"Most top teams in the Premier League now are nearly always playing with a back four and so for me, if you’re playing with four at the back instead of three, you can mix it up a little bit more as well.
"Some people think about the old fashioned 4-4-2 but then I quite like 4-3-3 when you’ve got good forwards. I think United are still capable of doing that, going with the back four.
"Whatever the manager wants to set up, if it's with the back five, you have to get off to a good start and score the first goal and then counter attack against teams. I think it's a good system then.
"If you're chasing the game, I always feel that you're lacking a midfield player or a forward so you're short in numbers because you've got the five at the back.

"I would like to see him be a bit more flexible but it looks like he's got his mind and he said it all last season that he's got his mind set on the back five so it's up to him and the players to show that they really can play in that system.

"They need to take on board what the manager's trying to achieve and pick it up as the season goes on because it is still early in the season and we have played against two very good teams who are going to be up there challenging for the title. So it has been quite a difficult start."
Robson is one of the finest midfielders to have represented United and he also shared his thoughts on Kobbie Mainoo, who is yet to start a Premier League game this season.

"Back in my days, Paul Ince was an underrated player and great to play with because Ince was quick, he could tackle, he was a really good passer of the ball and I think Ince was a very underrated player," said Robson.

"Why he was underrated is because the United fans were not pleased that he fell out with Sir Alex and then he went to Inter and he came back and played for Liverpool, so all the Man United fans didn’t like that, a Man United player who's done really well going to Liverpool.

"I definitely do (think Mainoo could be the next Ince). When I heard that Mainoo might be leaving the club, I was really against it. I think he's a real talent. Last year, he had quite a few injuries and couldn't get going but the year before that, he was outstanding and he looked as if he had great potential.

"As long as he keeps his feet on the ground and works really hard at it, he could be a really good player. I know he's more attacking but Mainoo can do the defending if you put it on him, and that's what he's got to do.
"He's got to get his overall game a little bit more established and then I think he would go really well with Bruno being the more advanced midfield player."

Last season was stop-start for Mainoo due to a few small injuries and concerns about where he fits into Amorim's system. Amorim played the midfielder in different positions, even using him as a false nine.
Mainoo relocated to the deeper midfield role in pre-season this summer, but Amorim raised eyebrows when he said Mainoo was competing with Bruno Fernandes for a start.
The youngster subsequently requested to leave on loan in the final days of the window, which was denied.

headline: Manchester United can complete seven-year transfer mission for just £17m
body: Manchester United may seemingly already be putting plans in place for the January transfer window. One area of the squad has been the subject of plenty of speculation following the defeat to Manchester City in the Manchester derby.

United may have signed three new forwards, a left-back and a goalkeeper during the summer transfer window, but a lot has been said about the need to sign a new midfielder. Brighton star Carlos Baleba was heavily linked with signing for United, but a move never materialised with the Seagulls reportedly demanding a fee in excess of £100million for the Cameroon international.

With the summer transfer window now closed, a fresh report has now emerged claiming that United are interested in Al-Hilal midfielder Ruben Neves. A report in the Daily Briefing has claimed that a €20million (£17million) deal could be on the cards with Neves apparently keen to return to Europe.

This is not the first time that United have been linked with signing Neves. Reports first emerged back in 2018 claiming that United were interested in signing the Portugal international during his time at Wolves.

United would certainly benefit from a new option in midfield. What will be key is how determined United are to sign Baleba, and if they have a realistic chance of getting a deal over the line.

headline: Jose Mourinho return confirmed just days after Ruben Amorim comments on job
body: Jose Mourinho has been appointed as Benfica's new manager, with his latest sabbatical from football lasting fewer than four weeks. The former Chelsea, Manchester United and Real Madrid chief was dismissed by Fenerbahce at the end of August following just over 12 months at the helm.
His rapid departure came 48 hours after the Turkish outfit were knocked out of the Champions League play-offs by his new employers Benfica.
Mourinho's team were defeated by former Premier League boss Bruno Lage, though he too was relieved of his duties this week after an inconsistent beginning to the campaign.
'The Special One' commenced his managerial journey with Benfica in 2000 but endured less than a full campaign after clashing with the club's president.
Now aged 62, Mourinho makes his return to Benfica and is anticipated to oversee his inaugural training session on Thursday.
Speaking prior to his appointment being formally confirmed, Mourinho disclosed he had no reservations about returning to his previous club.
He said: "What I can confirm is that, before I caught the plane, Benfica asked me if I was interested in coaching them.

"I said yes. I said I was abroad and that when I returned to Portugal I would have all the interest in talking with them. My nature is wanting to coach. I told myself that I wanted to balance myself emotionally.
"I didn't want to say yes to the wrong club, just because I am a workaholic. When asked if I wanted to coach Benfica, I did not think twice. It interests me."

Ruben Amorim, the current Manchester United manager, has also been mentioned as a potential successor following Lage's dismissal, with his future at Old Trafford looking uncertain. The ex-Sporting boss has had a challenging first year in England, managing to secure only one victory from United's initial four Premier League matches.
Despite this, the United board maintains their support for the manager, with another review scheduled after three more games, during the upcoming international break.
In light of the ongoing speculation, Norohna Lopes, who is vying for the Benfica presidency, was questioned about the likelihood of securing the Red Devils' boss.

He responded: "Ruben Amorim? He's a great coach, he has a contract with Manchester United. I won't comment on that. Of course I like him. He's a great coach and a Benfica fan. I don't have a contract for Ruben to sign."

The return of Mourinho to Benfica also puts an end to rumours of a comeback to the English top tier. He has already had two stints with Chelsea, clinching the Premier League title thrice, in addition to managing Manchester United and Tottenham.
Previously, he hinted at being open to leading a club not participating in European competition, following several disputes with UEFA.

"I think the best thing I have to do is, when I leave Fenerbahce, I go to a club that does not play UEFA competitions," Mourinho stated. "If any club in England from the bottom of the table needs a coach in two years, I am ready to go."

headline: Marcus Rashford gesture ahead of Barcelona Champions League clash speaks volumes
body: Marcus Rashford has shown that he's fully focused on Barcelona by sharing a message with fans on Instagram.

The 27-year-old Manchester United forward is currently enjoying a season-long loan with the Catalan giants after falling out of favour at Old Trafford following Ruben Amorim's arrival last November. And it appears as though the England international settling into life at the Camp Nou well, if his latest social media post is anything to go by.

With Barcelona heading to St James' Park to face Newcastle United in the Champions League at 8pm on Thursday evening, Rashford took to social media to share a matchday graphic which featured himself, Pedri and Pau Cubarsi. Underneath the three, the poster also read: "Un dia de partit," which translates to "matchday'."

It's also the name of a song that Barcelona fans sing at games, showing the immense bond between the club and its supporters. While it is unknown as to whether Rashford will get the nod to start on Thursday evening ahead of Raphinha or Lamine Yamal, the Englishman has certainly hit the ground running in Spain.

He has featured in each of Barca's four La Liga games this season so far, starting in their 3-2 win over Levante last month as well as their 6-0 demolition of Valencia at the weekend; albeit, he is yet to score his first goal. However, he will hope to make an impact on familiar soil on Thursday evening given the chance.

Unbeaten this season, with three wins and a draw to their name, Barcelona head to Tyneside in high spirits as they hope to kickstart their Champions League campaign in style. They will play a Newcastle side which has struggled to get going in the Premier League this term, after a difficult summer transfer window.

Talismanic striker Alexander Isak left the club in a British record £125million transfer to Liverpool after a summer of discontent in the north east - with the Magpies bringing in VfB Stuttgart forward Nick Woltemade and Brentford's Yoane Wissa as replacements.

It's been a tough start to the Premier League for Newcastle, who have taken just four points from their first four matches. The Magpies were held to a goalless draw by Aston Villa on opening weekend, before suffering a heart-breaking 3-2 loss to reigning champions Liverpool.

Another 0-0 stalemate with Leeds United followed, before Woltemade came to the rescue against Wolves at the weekend to hand his new club a 1-0 win on home soil. Newcastle's clash with Barcelona isn't the only Champions League clash that Premier League fans will have their eyes on.

That's because Kevin De Bruyne returns to the Etihad Stadium in a slightly different shade of blue as Manchester City play host to his new club, Napoli. The Belgian midfielder parted ways with the Blues this summer after an incredible 10-year tenure, in which he clinched six Premier League titles, two FA Cups and a Champions League.

headline: BREAKING: Man United make major announcement as £666m boost explained
body: Manchester United have announced the results of their fourth quarter trading period for the year ended June 30, 2025.
United have reported revenues of £164 million for the fourth quarter, which contributes to record revenues for 2025 of £666.5m.
Those revenues were made during a period in which United finished in 15th place in the Premier League, their worst performance in the competition since it was created in 1992.

Due to their competing in the Europa League, the final of which they lost to Tottenham Hotspur, United saw broadcasting revenues slump by £50m to £173m given their participation in the Champions League the season before.

United expect an improvement to retail and merchandise revenues and a slight uplift in broadcasting revenues given an increase in Premier League broadcasting money offsetting the absence of the club from UEFA competition this season.
Sky will show at least 215 live Premier League games this season, an increase of up to 100 more.
The club also added that it 'remains committed to, and in compliance with, both the Premier League’s Profit and Sustainability Rules and UEFA’s Financial Fair Play Regulations'.
“As we settle into the 2025/26 season, we are working hard to improve the club in all areas," CEO Omar Berrada said.

"On the field, we are pleased with the additions we have made to our men’s and women’s first team squads over the summer, as we build for the long-term. Off the field, we are emerging from a period of structural and leadership change with a refreshed, streamlined organisation equipped to deliver on our sporting and commercial objectives.

“We are also investing to upgrade our infrastructure, including completion of the £50m redevelopment of our men’s first team building at Carrington, on time and on budget, following prior investment in our women’s team facilities, to create a world-class environment for our players and staff. Meanwhile, planning continues to meet our ambition of developing a new stadium at Old Trafford as part of a transformational regeneration of the surrounding community.

“To have generated record revenues during such a challenging year for the club demonstrates the resilience which is a hallmark of Manchester United. Our commercial business remains strong as we continue to deliver appealing products and experiences for our fans, and best-in-class value to our partners. As we start to feel the benefits of our cost-reduction programme, there is significant potential for improved financial performance, which will, in turn, support our overriding priority: success on the pitch.”

headline: Man United icon David Beckham's remarkable net worth after football as he launches new career
body: Manchester United icon David Beckham has shared his delight at launching his latest business venture in the United States, having made an unexpected career change since hanging up his boots.

The 50-year-old former England captain, who retired from professional football in 2013, discovered beekeeping during the COVID-19 lockdown five years ago and the hobby rapidly developed into something much more significant. The passion project has now evolved into a fully-fledged commercial enterprise, with the Manchester United legend establishing his own honey-based snack company called Bee Up.

Designed for youngsters as a nutritious substitute for traditional sweets, the products have now arrived on American shop floors, going on sale at major retailer Target. Understandably, Beckham was thrilled to see his goods on display and he marked the moment with an Instagram post of him stood in front of a packed shelf, which he captioned: "Swipe to see how excited I am seeing @beeupsnacks in @target".

Announcing the venture earlier this year, the former Three Lions captain explained: "My love of beekeeping and making my own honey began as a hobby and quickly grew into a passion. I built the hives with my sons, learned how to care for the bees, and mastered the art of harvesting one of nature's most powerful superfoods.

"As a father and former athlete, it's always been important to me to give my kids wholesome alternatives to sweets. That's why I created BEEUP-a new snack brand rooted in honey, my love for family, and active living.

"Whether it's early mornings, after-school sports, or weekend adventures, BEEUP delivers better energy-one delicious bite at a time. This time-tested superfood tastes delicious and provides the energy kids need - perfect for fueling up before practice, lessons, or games."

Beckham discussed his passion for beekeeping whilst being filmed for the Netflix documentary series about his life, which was released in 2023. The opening scenes of the series featured him collecting honey from a beehive at his lavish Cotswolds estate, while his wife Victoria looked on and playfully suggested he market the honey as 'DB Sticky Stuff'.

The football legend is, of course, no stranger to commercial enterprises, having built an enormous personal wealth through various strategic moves beyond the football pitch, supplementing the vast fortune he made during his playing career. The 2025 Sunday Times Rich List, published earlier this year, revealed that Beckham and ex-Spice Girl Victoria boast a staggering combined fortune of £500 million.

Business Insider reports that the former United and Real Madrid midfielder had amassed an impressive $800 million (£587 million) by the time he retired 12 years ago. At his peak, he commanded the highest salary in world football, whilst his five-year deal with LA Galaxy signed in 2008 would equate to approximately £190 million today.

However, Beckham has also significantly boosted his personal wealth through a series of profitable sponsorships and business deals, collaborating with major brands such as Emporio Armani, Gillette, PepsiCo, H&M, Breitling and Adidas over the years. Additionally, he's launched his own line of fragrances and lent his name to a range of products from sunglasses to video games.

The Netflix documentary is thought to have netted the former footballer around £20 million alone, while in 2023 he amassed an impressive £72.6 million thanks to his sponsorships and production company. He also inked a 10-year deal to serve as an ambassador for Qatar, which reportedly earned him around £125 million from the country.

However, the crowning glory of Brand Beckham is his Major League Soccer team, Inter Miami. When Beckham negotiated his move to LA Galaxy in 2007, he was offered the option to purchase an expansion team in any market for just $25 million. Today, with superstars like Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez in the squad, the franchise is now believed to be valued at over $1 billion, doubling in worth between 2023 and 2024.

In addition to earning astronomical sums from his various ventures, Beckham is no stranger to lavish spending, owning over a dozen properties that make up his remarkable portfolio, estimated to be worth around £70 million. This includes a luxury penthouse in Miami, purchased for £17.5 million, as well as a London townhouse valued at approximately £30 million.
The ex-footballer also boasts a 130-foot superyacht, which reportedly cost him around £16 million, and his car collection is estimated to be worth over £2 million in total.

headline: Former Man United boss Jose Mourinho shows true colours to sacked manager as deal agreed
body: Jose Mourinho has shown his true colours ahead of his potential appointment as the new Benfica head coach. The former Manchester United boss was sacked by Fenerbahce at the end of last month, just two days after they were knocked out of the Champions League play-offs by the Portuguese giants.

Benfica held the Turkish outfit to a goalless draw at the Chobani Stadium before running away 1-0 victors in Lisbon. Despite securing the Eagles' qualification to Europe's top-flight competition, Bruno Lage was sacked shortly after their opening league phase match.
On Tuesday night, Benfica lost to Qarabag at the Estadio da Luz. The Portuguese giants squandered a two-goal lead, with Oleksiy Kashchuk firing the Azerbaijani champions ahead in the final minutes.

"A coach representing a club of this size must be one with the ability to bring this team to the levels we demand and give us the titles we desire. There's no point in talking about names here. No coach has been appointed, nor has any coach been mentioned to represent Benfica in the future."

Mourinho was quickly linked with a long-awaited return to Benfica, and now he looks set to put pen to paper. On Wednesday afternoon, the former United boss was mobbed by journalists at the Tires Aerodrome – an airport just outside of Lisbon.

While Mourinho kept his cards close to his chest, he didn't hide his interest in the vacancy. As quoted by Portuguese outlet A Bola, the 62-year-old, draped in a Benfica scarf, said: "Before boarding the plane, they asked me if I might be interested.
"And I said yes, I might be interested. Benfica officially asked me if I might be interested. I said I was abroad and that when I returned to Portugal, I'd be happy to speak with people.

"When I was faced with the possibility of coaching Benfica, I didn't think twice: I'm interested," asserted Mourinho, who then paid his respects to his predecessor. "He needs to do what we all do –grieve," he added.

"I don't think there's a coach who doesn't leave frustrated and thinking things could have turned out differently. I look at him with immense respect and solidarity because I went through the same thing. And not long ago.
"What I said about him a month and a half ago, I repeat – he's a great coach who had a group of important players whom I congratulated. And they know I'm not exactly a great example of fair play."

Mourinho added: "Congratulating them, telling them that the best won and deserved to win, wasn't easy. He knows Benfica very well, he played against this team three times, he often praised the squad, he said I was happy, he will be even more so with Sudakov and Dodi [Lukebakio] arriving."

headline: RAILSTON: Bryan Mbeumo's screams to teammate spoke volumes about Manchester United problem
body: Manchester United suffered a 3-0 defeat to Manchester City on Sunday afternoon.
Phil Foden scored the opening goal in the 18th minute, finding the corner with a header after some excellent work from Jeremy Doku.
Erling Haaland scored early in the second half and then added another with just over 20 minutes remaining to take the game away from United.
Here are the talking points and moments you might have missed from the game:
Bayindir's confidence is shattered
Altay Bayindir wanted the ground to swallow him up when he conceded the third goal. Haaland finished with ease to net his second of the game and a desolate Bayindir stared at the turf.

Bryan Mbeumo was spotted on the halfway line trying to get Bayindir's attention. Mbeumo was screaming at his goalkeeper, trying to tell him to keep his head up, and he eventually got the message across.

Ruben Amorim confirmed at his pre-match press conference that Bayindir would start, despite making mistakes against Arsenal and Burnley. That backfired because Bayindir was shaky from the first whistle.
He was a bundle of nerves and went down to the ground far too easily for Haaland's first goal. Mbeumo sensed he was low on confidence after conceding City's third and tried to encourage him.
It feels like only a matter of time before Senne Lammens is the first choice goalkeeper.
City fans do the Poznan
City fans brought out The Poznan after going three goals ahead. The fans in front of the press box turned around in glee to face journalists and the dance spread around the entire lower tier.

United only trailed by a goal at the interval and could have found a way back into the contest, but they capitulated in the space of 15 minutes and a lot of fans in the away section started to leave early.
Amorim has overseen some humiliating defeats and a 3-0 loss to City will be added to the catalogue.
The terrace exchange

Former City director of football Txiki Begiristain was shown on the big screen. He received warm applause from the home support, but United fans responded: "You cheating b*******, you know what you are."
There was another rendition of the chant just minutes into the contest, but City fans fired back after taking the lead through Foden, singing their own version of the Amorim chant.
"Crying from the Stretford End... He'll turn the Reds around," they taunted before reverting to "Old Trafford is falling down, Amorim is a f****** clown. Glazers staying 10 more years".
There was a debate on a radio station about whether United and City are still proper rivals, but you only need to listen to matchgoing fans to know that was a stupid suggestion.
United fans who work with City supporters will dread going to work this morning.
United need more leaders
Noussair Mazraoui went down with an injury just outside the City box at the start of the second half and Doku approached him to gesture that he was exaggerating the extent of the issue.
City fans whistled at Mazraoui while he took his time to get back to his feet. Leny Yoro began to make his way over, seemingly looking to protect his colleague from Doku's rant.
Yoro was the only United player to offer protection to Mazraoui. The dressing room needs more characters like Yoro.
The midfield is a problem

The decision to start Ugarte raised eyebrows. The midfielder had been hooked at half-time against Grimsby Town after failing to track back for their first goal and was an unused substitute against Burnley.
Amorim was expected to continue with Casemiro and Bruno Fernandes, but he handed another chance to Ugarte because he felt the 24-year-old's pressing ability and energy would be valuable.

Ugarte vindicated Amorim's decision to start him. He was the best player in a red shirt in the first half, breaking up play and stifling City attacks, and he earned warm applause from his manager when he played a wonderful pass over the top to Mbeumo, who was flagged offside.
However, Fernandes had another off day - he was poor when he missed a penalty against Fulham at Craven Cottage last month - and ultimately let the partnership down.
The midfield is a problem for Amorim, but United didn't believe that area was a priority in the summer.
Beautiful tribute for Hatton
The death of legendary boxer Ricky Hatton was announced on Sunday morning. Hatton was a lifelong City supporter and was expected to attend Sunday's derby.

There was a minute's applause held for Hatton prior to the game and the players wore black armbands. Both sets of fans joined in with the tribute and chanted together: "There's only one Ricky Hatton."
Hatton was a proper Mancunian icon and it was heartwarming to hear City and United fans sing his name together.

headline: LUCKHURST: Ruben Amorim explains why Bruno Fernandes is still playing in midfield for Manchester United
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim defended his decision to play Bruno Fernandes in central midfield for the fourth game running at Manchester City.
United lost 3-0 at the Etihad to leave them with four points from their first four Premier League games, their worst start to a season since 1992-93.

Fernandes has dropped back into midfield this season following the signings of Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo, who had occupied the two playmaker roles before Cunha suffered an injury against Burnley two weeks ago.
Amorim picked Amad alongside Mbeumo behind Benjamin Sesko while Fernandes was partnered by Manuel Ugarte, having started alongside Casemiro in the previous three league outings.
United only have three out-and-out central midfielders in Ugarte, Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo, with the latter yet to start in the league this term.

"Guys, I understand how football is," Amorim said. "The results will dictate all the narratives. Against Arsenal, who is playing against Arsenal? Do you think we play well? Do you think we are the better team? Do you think that (Martin) Odegaard, (Declan) Rice and (Martin) Zubimendi are three top midfielders? They play with three. We play with two. One was Casemiro, the other was Bruno.

"Sometimes it is the dynamic of the team. Sometimes it is an opportunity that you score. I see it that way. I know that it is really hard for people [to understand]. The fans don't want to hear me saying these things. I know that they are not going to listen to nothing and be upset. With that, I cannot do nothing.

"I am trying to be rational and I don't lie to myself. I see the record. I understand the frustration of everybody and I understand any decision that came with that. But that conversation about the two midfielders, the pair, Kobbie and Manu, I understand all these narratives. But then when I look at certain games, we play with two. It is the same thing.
"Today when you imagine the game, why not use Amad, Bryan, Sesko and Bruno behind with the ball? To be the first guy receiving the ball and then with a lot of pace in front.
"I am trying to do different things, trying to imagine the game. And then when you don't win, it doesn't work, you take the critics. But that's it."

headline: Anderson deal, Baleba signed - Ruben Amorim can save Man United job with dream January transfers
body: Amie is a football writer covering clubs across the country, she has been a football fan all of her life and supports Leicester City. She graduated with a degree in Sport and Exercise Psychology in 2015. Amie has previous experience in local radio in Leicester and Leicestershire.
It has been a disappointing start to the Premier League season for Manchester United.

One win, one draw, and two losses in their first four games of the season have left them in 14th place in the table, with four points from a possible 12 available. A 3-0 loss against rivals Manchester City on Sunday afternoon was one to forget for United fans.

It has also raised questions again about Ruben Amorim's future. The summer transfer window saw the club spend around £200 million on new players, including striker Benjamin Sesko and forwards Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha.
The first games of the campaign have, however, shown the problems that remain in the squad. With the summer transfer window now closed, work will have to be done in January to address those issues.

Amid growing pressure on his position, Amorim may already be looking to the work he can do when the window reopens if he is still at the club. Addressing problems in the winter window could relieve some of the pressure on the Portuguese boss.
Here’s a look at what a dream January window could look like for Amorim and United.
There’s no doubt that midfield reinforcements should be the priority for United going into the January window. The club did make moves for players in the summer.

Brighton’s strong not-for-sale stance on Carlos Baleba caused them to walk away from any potential deal. But United could potentially try again in January in the hope that the Seagulls may be more open to a sale.

If that’s the case, then negotiations could start, with an agreement between all parties hopefully being reached. The arrival of Baleba could potentially help give Bruno Fernandes more freedom, even if he is playing in a deeper midfield role.

Another player linked with United in the last few days is Nottingham Forest’s Elliott Anderson. The player caught the eye with his performances for England against both Andorra and Serbia in the international break.

The former Newcastle man has shown how he can control games and dictate the play, something that United have been missing so far this season. However, like with Baleba, a deal may not be easy to do with Forest, who will be keen to keep hold of a key player, especially during the first transfer window with Ange Postecoglou at the helm.
Away from midfield, one other area where United probably need more cover is at right-back. Currently, Diego Dalot and Noussair Mazraoui are the two recognised right-backs in the squad.
An injury or suspension to just one will leave United short on options. United have again been linked with an interest in Inter’s Denzel Dumfries.
The full-back has recently admitted that he would be open to a Premier League move, and would add experience and quality to that side of defence.

If United did complete the signings of both Baleba and Anderson, or two deeper midfielders in the January window, then it would allow Kobbie Mainoo to leave the club on loan for the second half of the season. The midfielder outlined his desire to leave on a temporary deal during the summer, but United refused.
If the club can add to their midfield options, then it would free up the academy graduate to go out and get regular game time.

Another player who could go out on loan is Tyler Fredricson. Lisandro Martinez is expected to be back from injury in the next couple of months, if the centre-back can get up to speed quickly then it would provide enough defensive cover to allow the 20-year-old to go out and get more games.

Chido Obi could be a third candidate to go out on loan. After making his United debut last season, the striker is yet to make a matchday squad this season, and has been back playing for the U21 squad.
A loan deal could see him get more of a taste for first-team football in the second half of the season, and hopefully return a better player.
One player who could leave permanently is Tyrell Malacia. The full-back was linked with a move away in the summer, but a transfer never materialised.

headline: Ruben Amorim denial issued amid Man United sack pressure after new job claims
body: Ruben Amorim is reportedly being considered by Benfica after as sack pressure ramps up following his Manchester United side's dismal start to the campaign.

United lost 3-0 to Manchester City in the Manchester derby on Sunday and Amorim became the target of criticism from pundits. The Portuguese has now only won won eight of his 31 league games in charge since taking over from Erik ten Hag last November.

Despite being highly regarded in his native Portugal for his outstanding work at Sporting Clube de Portugal - ending their 19-year league title drought and leading them back into Europe - the last few months in England have not been easy for him.
Outsiders are keeping an eye on his situation and reports in Portugal claim he is being considered as a potential manager for Benfica.

Next month, the Portuguese giants will hold elections for a new president. Candidate Joao Noronha Lopes, together with former Benfica and Portugal international Nuno Gomes, who is running as vice-president, are reportedly considering Amorim as a potential coach.

The pair were in attendance at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday and, upon their return to Lisbon, were quizzed about the latest rumours.
Noronha Lopes explained: "We went to Manchester to watch the derby, and when we are together, we take the time to have meetings and prepare the future of Benfica.
"We didn't meet up with Bernardo Silva or Ruben Amorim after the game. I want to bring to Benfica a winning culture, which has talent, dedication and people who know how to win."
When quizzed if he would like to see Amorim as manager of Benfica in the near future, Noronha Lopes added: "Ruben is under contract with Manchester United and I won't comment on that."

Meanwhile, Gomes denied that their trip to Manchester had anything to do with the United manager. "I don't want to speak about that, I'm a friend of Ruben Amorim, and he has a contract with Manchester United," he added.
"We watched the game, Joao [Noronha Lopes] is a passionate football fan and I enjoyed this experience with him."

headline: RAILSTON: United youngster thanks Ruben Amorim for 'life-changing' experience
body: Ethan Williams has described the chance to play for Manchester United during the pre-season tour as "life-changing."
United travelled to the United States to compete in the Premier League Summer Series this summer, preparing for the new season with friendlies against West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton.
Ruben Amorim included a handful of youngsters from the academy in the travelling tour squad. Williams made the cut and scored his first senior goal in a 4-1 win against Bournemouth.

In August, Williams signed for Falkirk on a season-long loan. The forward made 17 appearances during his six-month loan with Cheltenham Town last term and will now try to develop his game in Scotland.

Speaking to the Daily Record, Williams said: “I played about 15 minutes against Bournemouth in Chicago in the summer. We won 4-1 and I scored. The whole team was really warming to me and the other young players. To play and score on tour was life-changing. Something I will never forget.

“Coming off the back of that, getting the opportunity to play here in a good league against good teams is really important to me. I just can’t wait to get my foot in the door and start pushing for starts."

Explaining his move to Falkirk, he said: “I’d been speaking to the manager (John McGlynn) and his coaches for quite some time over the summer. Going on tour with United it was quite difficult, communication wise. But once it was set in motion I was ready to come here. I’m happy to be here.
“It’s always good to know that a manager trusts you. For him to come to me and be interested is quite flattering. I’m proud to be here.
“The team has had back-to-back promotions and want to play aggressive football against the top teams. It’s a style I like as a winger. That’s what sold it on me.

“The Scottish Premiership is a very good league, comparable with leagues in England. My first experience of it was good. It was a really proud moment and I’m thankful the manager trusts me and gave me minutes."
Darren Fletcher was appointed as United's Under-18 manager in the summer, but his previous role involved keeping tabs on academy prospects and reporting on their progress.
Williams discussed his relationship with Fletcher, adding: "I’ve been a United fan for a long time. Him being in the team with the likes of Ronaldo and Rooney, they were the glory days of Man United.
“It’s quite an unreal experience when you step back and think ‘wow’ I’m actually talking with Darren Fletcher. It’s a mad experience for a young kid. But being up here and around it is a good thing.

“Darren was one of the first team assistant coaches, he’s with the U18s now but I’m in contact with him. He knows the game and is a big part of Manchester United. He’s someone that is looking to help me in my journey.

“He’s been asking how everything’s going. I told him I’ve settled well and the team is really welcoming. Everyone is really heartwarming with me and getting around the lads has been a good experience."

Williams' professional contract with United started in June 2024 and he was given the chance to train with FC-Lausanne's first team in October as part of an innovative agreement between the Swiss club and United.

Williams joined United's academy from Rochdale at Under-14 level. He is the nephew of Alex Williams, who rose to prominence in the early 1980s as one of the first black goalkeepers in the modern top flight, making more than 100 appearances for Manchester City in a trailblazing career.

headline: Ruben Amorim losing Man United dressing room as pressure grows after Manchester City defeat
body: Ruben Amorim is battling to maintain the trust of his Manchester United squad following their derby humiliation.
United's 3-0 thrashing at Manchester City has intensified the scrutiny on Amorim, with the Portuguese manager now fighting for his position.
It is believed several of United's experienced players have grown increasingly irritated and bewildered by Amorim's stubborn adherence to his tactical approach and formation.
Amorim's rigid formation and his unwillingness to consider alternative setups is said to have sparked significant unease among influential squad members.
Certain United stars are understood to believe Amorim is doing them a disservice by persistently demanding they operate within a system they are ill-suited to, reports the Mirror.

The pressure is building on Amorim to orchestrate a United revival after the disappointing beginning to their campaign, which has yielded just four points from four matches.
United are statistically the worst team of the ever-present top flight sides since his appointment on November 24.
However, the defiant 40 year-old stuck to his guns after the 3-0 defeat to City on Sunday, insisting that he will not alter his system and if the club wants a change they should look elsewhere.

"Guys, I understand that and I accept," Amorim said of his Premier League record. "It is not a record you should have in Manchester United. There are a lot of things - you have no idea what happened during these months - but I accept that. I am not going to change.

"When I want to change my philosophy, I will change. If not, you have to change the man. We will talk about that every game that we lose. I don't believe in that, in the system, or whatever. I believe in my way and I am going to play my way until I want to change.
"My message is that I am going to give everything. I will do everything, always thinking about what is best for the club. That was always the same message.
"It is not my decision, the rest (on whether United change manager). Until I am here, I will do my best. I really want to win games. I am suffering more than them."

headline: Man Utd legend Schmeichel had ‘never heard of’ Lammens as INEOS told who they ‘should’ve signed’
body: Legendary former Manchester United goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel has revealed he had “never heard of” Senne Lammens prior to the Red Devils being linked with him, and has told the club who they should’ve signed instead.

United were told throughout the summer that their goalkeepers were not up to scratch. For a man who reached a Champions League final with Inter Milan, it was hard to tell Andre Onana had been close to that level.
As such, in the final days of the summer, he was replaced by Lammens and loaned out to Trabzonspor.
Pior to Lammens’ signing, though, there were links with Emiliano Martinez and Gianluigi Donnarumma. The former has won the World Cup and the latter the Champions League.
Schmeichel feels those are the ilk of players United should have signed, instead of 23-year-old Lammens, from Royal Antwerp.
“We should have signed Emi Martinez. In fact, we should have gone for Gianluigi Donnarumma when we had the chance,” he said.
“With Martinez, everything was lined up and that felt like really good news, because he’s exactly the kind of goalkeeper Manchester United should have.
“As for Lammens, I’ll be honest, I’d never heard of him until the link came up.
“I know his stats are excellent across the top ten European leagues. But that was with Antwerp in Belgium, in a team that finished fifth.
“Stats don’t show how you react after a mistake, or how you cope with the pressure of Manchester United. That pressure is unlike anywhere else in football.”
Lammens has a fantastic save percentage, but has never played in a top-five league, has featured in the Champions League just once, and is yet to make his national team debut for Belgium.
He is still yet to play for United despite being in place for their last Premier League game – the 3-0 loss to Manchester City.
Indeed, Altay Bayindir was preferred between the sticks, despite rumours he could have been allowed to leave in the summer, and the goalkeeper having made mistakes during his time in the United net.
When Lammens does get his first crack is unclear, as most would have expected he’d have been in immediately after his signing.

In any case, Schmeichel was disappointed that he was the man signed, not a better option, and having one of the best players ever in your position, at the club you now play for, already on your back, is not a good start.
Peter Schmeichel has questioned Manchester United letting a pair of stars leave the club, and he “hopes” one of them scores “25 goals” to show them what they’re missing.
The brother of new Man Utd signing Senne Lammens attempted to stop him from joining the Red Devils but the Premier League club “gave him the best feeling”.
Manchester United lost their third game of the season on Sunday as rivals Manchester City beat them 3-0 in a comprehensive performance.
Man Utd legend Peter Schmeichel reckons the Red Devils could have saved £73m by keeping Rasmus Hojlund and not signing Benjamin Sesko.
Wayne Rooney hit out at one Manchester United “panic buy” after Ruben Amorim’s side suffered a one-sided 3-0 loss against Manchester City.

headline: Man Utd told to sack Amorim for former manager or ‘they’ll be playing Rotherham’ next season
body: Man Utd boss Ruben Amorim should be sacked and replaced by former Red Devils head coach Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, according to Jamie O’Hara.
It is similar form to that which saw them finish 15th in the Premier League last term under Amorim and miss out on European qualification.
Widespread reports indicate that Amorim is not currently under heaps of pressure from the board but that if he looks likely to fail to qualify for Europe then the Man Utd hierarchy are ready to act.

headline: Schmeichel questions Man Utd for letting two stars leave as he ‘hopes’ forward scores ’25 goals’
body: Peter Schmeichel has questioned Manchester United letting a pair of stars leave the club, and he “hopes” one of them scores “25 goals” to show them what they’re missing.
United allowed 10 players to leave this summer – Antony and Alejandro Garnacho permanently, and Rasmus Hojlund, Marcus Rashford and Andre Onana among those on loan.
Antony and Rashford had both spent time out on loan last season, while Hojlund and Onana underperformed.

Speaking on some of the exits, United legend Schmeichel suggested Antony’s was acceptable, but Hojlund still has a lot to offer to the Red Devils, and he hopes they can see that while he’s out on loan.
He said: “With Antony, it’s different. He was never good enough for Manchester United. Yes, he scored on his debut, but very quickly you could see he didn’t have what it takes for the Premier League.

“In Holland, playing in a dominant team, he looked good. But at United, the pace is relentless from the first minute to the last, the pressure is constant, and every opponent raises their game. To succeed here, you need something extra, and he didn’t have it. He’s moved on, and we wish him well.

“The one that really pains me is Højlund. I honestly believe he could have been a 25-goal-a-season striker for Manchester United. The problem wasn’t him – it was the way the team played. The system didn’t suit him. When players like Garnacho or Rashford got the ball, they looked only to shoot. The ball into the No.9 never came, even though Rasmus was making really good runs.

“The fans saw it. They loved him because he fought, he ran, he gave everything, and he had to play every game because there were no other strikers. Of course, when you don’t score as a striker, people point to it again and again. But what more could he do without service?

“I’ve seen what he can do when he’s on form and gets the right service. That’s why I’m glad it’s only a loan. I hope he scores 25 goals, and that people at Old Trafford are then thinking: ‘We have to bring him back.’

“With [Matheus] Cunha and [Bryan] Mbeumo now providing service, and Bruno [Fernandes] playing further up the pitch, I still believe he could be a fantastic striker for Manchester United. He’s already scored after just 30 minutes for Napoli, which shows his quality. He’s still our player, and that’s the positive.”
Hojlund scored on his Serie A debut for Napoli, playing alongside Scott McTominay – last season’s Serie A player of the year after leaving United – who also has one goal so far this season.
Schmeichel seems dejected at the fact the midfielder was ever allowed to leave.

And now journalist Graeme Bailey has told United In Focus that the Man Utd hierarchy are “furious about is the potential of leaks again”.
Bailey said: ‘The one thing the club are furious about is the potential of leaks again, seeing stories about players and squad members not being convinced by Amorim or his tactics.
‘The club thought they had really stamped this out, they see it as totally destructive to what they are trying to do.
‘United firmly believe they are building something, but they won’t and can’t allow internal discontent to impact on the club as a whole.’

Speaking about his midfield in the aftermath of the 3-0 Manchester Derby defeat to Man City, Man Utd boss Amorim said: “It’s the same thing, it’s always the same conversation. They [City] put four in the middle, we have three central defenders and two midfielders.
“You can see Bryan [Mbeumo] is always inside and [Benjamin] Sesko is there, so that conversation is always the same thing.
“We play last year the same way – of course with difference because the opponent is playing in a different way against Liverpool, against all these teams in the same way.

“So it’s not the midfielders because, again, if you feel that what you are going to do in the first goal has to do with the amount of midfielders. Doku receives the ball, turns to the defence and then takes two guys inside the box. Then the second half, we start really well with two midfielders.

“You are near the box controlling the game and then throw-in, goal. Third goal, you are controlling the game, trying to open the game, Bryan has a great opportunity, Amad is pushing on the side, we had some distraction with going to the ball, Haaland has all the field to run so it’s not to do with the midfielders.

“It’s the way you want to see the games. I saw a lot of teams playing here [at the Etihad Stadium] with five midfielders just blocking and they suffer more than us. I see a lot of games from Manchester United playing here with a lot of midfielders.

“Opportunities sometimes with one, two, so it’s not about that. Again, sometimes we play with the three defenders, five defenders, sometimes it’s five midfielders or two midfielders. It depends on the game of the opponent.”
